Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
The work they called social work called to me. Helping the lost children, the broken families. That's where I saw myself, in the Division of Family and Children Services. A life dedicated to service, respect, and the hard-won ethics of the trade. To mend the frayed edges of families, to offer a hand to those in need. These weren't just words, these were the things that lived inside me.

I'd always felt a pull towards helping, but the path was obscured. High school, college, a parade of faces running from their troubles, or clinging to crutches that wouldn't hold. I watched it all unfold, and that's how I found myself with a degree in Psychology, still searching.

A summer lay ahead, a time for rest, for reflection. A friend's house, a boy sitting stiffly on the couch, his eyes wide with fear. Sixteen years old, escaping the storm of his home. Abusive parents, he said. The next day, the police were called. I felt a pull, a need to do something. I drove to the house, spoke to the officers, offered what little knowledge my degree had given me. They asked me to speak to the parents. 

Their faces were tight, their words a tangled web of excuses. "Manipulative," they called their son, for seeking help. "Simple disputes," they said, as if the boy's terror was some childish game. That day, I knew. This wasn't just a career, it was a calling.

Social justice, another cornerstone. We talk of individual worth, but what does it mean? We mourn the lost, yet strive to be the same. I don't want to be a shadow, a reflection. I've always fought against the mold, against the quiet conformity. My hair a riot of color, my clothes a statement, piercings piercing the accepted norms. A voice for the voiceless, a protector of the marginalized. I've marched, I've spoken, I've challenged the status quo. This is who I am, and this is what I will continue to fight for.

The paper here takes up the tangled threads of insomnia, weaving them through the looms of biology and society. The biological strand speaks of inheritable codes, of the body's own machinery gone awry. It probes the depths of genes and the hum of neurons, tracing the pathways of sleep and wakefulness through the labyrinthine brain. The sociocultural thread, it delves into the world outside, the web of circumstance that shapes our nights. It considers the weight of race and class, the echoes of history and the burdens of place. 

This examination, it seeks to unravel the mysteries of insomnia through the lens of these two models, to illuminate the interplay between nature and nurture. It sifts through the evidence, the shards of research, to decipher the strengths and weaknesses of each claim. 

Insomnia, it can be a shadow cast by itself, or a specter accompanying other maladies of the mind. It can be a whisper in the night, a phantom limb, or a roaring beast. It can be a primary disorder, a dyssomnia, or a parasomnia, a disruption of the natural rhythms of sleep. It can be a consequence of medical strife or the ghosts of substances past.

The biological model, it delves into the very essence of the sleepless soul. It points to the hypothalamus, the conductor of our inner orchestra, and its conductor's baton, the orexin neurons. It speaks of receptors, GABAB in particular, that whisper secrets of sleep and wakefulness. It reveals how these receptors, when activated or silenced, can summon slumber or banish it.

A study, it reveals,  probing the depths of the mouse brain, uncovers the presence of GABAB receptors on these orexin neurons.  This activation, it suggests, can usher in the embrace of sleep. But a disruption, a glitch in this delicate dance, can leave one tossing and turning, a prisoner in the cage of wakefulness.

This, it warns, is not merely a tale of mice, but a reflection of our own biological tapestry. If these receptors, these tiny architects of sleep, are indeed shaped by our genes, then the seeds of insomnia can be planted long before the first sleepless night.

The sociocultural model, it lifts its gaze from the microscopic to the vast expanse of human experience. It recognizes that sleep is not a solitary affair, but a dance woven into the fabric of our lives. It acknowledges the influence of race, class, and the invisible hand of history.

If the biological model speaks of genes and neurons, the sociocultural model speaks of the world that shapes us. It recognizes that poverty, stress, and trauma can cast long shadows over our nights. It understands that the burden of inequality can manifest in sleepless nights.

The paper turns its gaze upon three facets of Central Auditory Processing Disorder. First, a sketch of the affliction itself. Then, the matter of diagnosis, the signs, the whispers in the dark. And finally, a glimpse into the ways a teacher in a classroom, a world of noise and clamor, might help a child lost in the sound. 

Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD, they call it. Auditory Processing Disorder too. It speaks to the way the brain, the hard-wired machinery of the mind, makes use of what it hears. A matter of efficiency, of effectiveness. The American Speech-Language-Hearing Association, they say it's "the perceptual processing of auditory information in the CNS and the neurobiologic activity that underlies that processing." The brain, they say, failing to translate the sounds, to sift the words from the hum. A child who hears, yet cannot understand. Not deaf, but adrift in a sea of sound. The brain, they say, doesn't work right.

They first spoke of this disorder in the fifties, "auditory imperception" they called it. Researchers, poking and probing at children with speech troubles. Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari, in Italy, they began to fashion tests. And Kimura, he came along and spoke of "dichotic testing," a way to map the brain's response. A conference in '77, a spark, a fire ignited.

CAPD, it wears many faces. A child may not hear sounds in space, may struggle to tell one sound from another, may miss the patterns, the whispers in the wind. Sarcasm, a change in tone, it passes them by. One sound drowned out by the next.  The world a jumbled mess.  

Diagnosis is a careful dance. Observation, tests, a hunt for the signs. Audiologists, speech therapists, psychologists, they all play a part. Questionnaires, tests with sounds, a symphony of stimuli. No single test, no magic bullet. The cause, a mystery.

The play, Twelfth Night, it speaks of a kind of dangerous magic, this illusion. A man or woman cloaked in another's skin, a shadow play of the self. It says that while the lie can serve, for a time, it can also become a trap. A man or woman lost in the guise, swallowed whole. To shed the illusion is to risk loneliness, to stand naked before the world. Some will accept the truth, others will recoil, their eyes wide with betrayal.

And the deception of gender, that's a wound that cuts deeper. Why does a soul seek to become something it's not? What drives a woman to don the mask of a man, to become a phantom in a foreign land? In Viola's case, it's the cold grip of survival. She seeks shelter in the guise of a man, a shield against the darkness.

But this protection comes at a price. She is cut off from the wellspring of her own kind, adrift in a sea of unfamiliar faces. And the lie takes root, twisting and blooming into something unforeseen. Olivia, blinded by the illusion, falls for her charade, mistaking the man for a man. 

And Orsino, he too, is caught in the web. A love unspoken, a yearning for something beyond reach, fueled by the masquerade. But is it the man that Olivia desires, or something deeper, a hidden truth she cannot name?  Perhaps, in the shadow play of Twelfth Night, Shakespeare shows us the way our own desires can be shaped by the masks we wear. He reveals the fragility of truth, the way it can be both a source of pain and a catalyst for understanding.

Olivia, she moves quickly from one illusion to another, a fickle heart swayed by appearances.  In the end, she sees Viola not as a lover, but as a sister, a bond forged in the crucible of deception.  And so, the play leaves us with a question: what are we willing to sacrifice for love, for truth, for a semblance of self?

The stain of the Reich stretched long and dark across the African sun.  The slaughter of the Ovaherero and Nama, a reckoning etched in blood, stood as a testament to the brutality of their rule.  But empires, like men, are not simple beasts.  The German dominion, sprawled across the continent, wore many faces.  Its policies, like the shifting sands, varied with the winds of place. Education, a flickering candle in the vast darkness, burned with different intensities in each.

When the British came, inheriting the husk of German East Africa, they found a people touched by knowledge, literate souls walking in the sun.  In Kamerun, and other shadowed corners of the empire, whispers spoke of the Germans' efforts, their attempts to bring light to the darkness.  But in South West Africa, a different tale unfolded.  A land where the government, with a cold indifference, left the fate of native education to the meager ministrations of missionaries.  

Europeans, the favored sons, were ushered into the halls of learning, their education nurtured and controlled by the state's iron hand.  The natives, however, remained shrouded in ignorance, the vast majority untouched by the glow of knowledge.  This disparity, a scar upon the land, lingered long after the Reich had crumbled. Other colonies boasted a people awakened, literate and empowered. South West Africa, however, remained trapped in the grip of darkness.

This paper seeks to unravel the threads that bind this history, to shed light upon the reasons for this divergence.  It delves into the attitudes of the settlers, the whispers of the colonial authorities, and the social, political, and economic forces that shaped the destiny of a people.

The study of German colonial education is a vast and intricate tapestry, woven from primary sources in the German tongue, penned in the twilight of the empire.  These early works sought to document the shape of education in the colonies, to illuminate the workings of a system both complex and contradictory.  Later writings, in the English tongue, expanded the discourse, comparing the educational landscapes of the various colonies and dissecting the nuances of their practices.  Cohen, in his seminal work, cast a critical eye upon the educational systems of both South West Africa and East Africa, drawing a stark contrast.  He argues that the settler population, a tide of white desires, shaped the distinct features of South West Africa's educational system.


The land itself, a canvas of arid desert and temperate plains, offered a relative respite from the scorching heat of other colonies. This, in turn, attracted a steady influx of European settlers, swelling their numbers to nearly fifteen thousand by 1913.  In East Africa, the colony with the next largest settler population, the numbers paled in comparison, a mere five thousand souls.

The classification of Popular Music, a tangled web spun over a century, now encompasses a multitude of genres so numerous they defy easy listing. Each, from rap to rock, country to jazz, folk and beyond, gives birth to subgenres and sub-subgenres, a sprawling, ever-branching family tree.  Heavy metal, a child of rock, has emerged in the past forty years as a genre of remarkable diversity and expression. Its music, a tempest of sound, channels a spectrum of emotions, though often veering toward the shadowed recesses of the human heart. 

From its nascent days, metal's flexibility was evident. Bands, drawn to its power, began carving out their own niches, spawning subgenres in turn, each a reflection of its own particular vision. And so the chain continues, a labyrinth of sound where the boundaries blur, and the question arises: what, precisely, is heavy metal?

It has become a chameleon, absorbing elements from other genres, yet its origins remain a vital touchstone. To truly understand the metal that reverberates today, one must first trace its lineage, for it is more than a mere genre—it is a movement, a force that has reshaped the landscape of music.

Metal is, in many ways, a child of darkness. A "music of more"—more bass, more volume, more raw power, more theatricality. Less innocence, more virtuosity. The musicians, masters of their instruments, wield their craft with a precision that pierces the soul.

And there's a darkness that seeps into its very core, a darkness born of the psychedelic drug boom of the mid-seventies, a time when minds expanded and boundaries blurred.  The music, infused with the otherworldly, became a conduit for the experiences, both joyful and terrifying, that these substances wrought. Metal's visceral qualities, a stark departure from the prevailing pop music of the era, tapped into a primal wellspring of emotion, echoing the dark, brooding themes of the Romantic era.

Lyrics, sharp as daggers, capture this essence:


These words, from the Beatles' "Helter Skelter," expose the darker side of the Fab Four. A song of highs and lows, a reflection of the drug-induced haze, it is considered by some to be one of the first heavy metal songs. It was a response, a challenge, to the Rolling Stones' own foray into heavier, darker territory. The Beatles, proving they could match the Stones' intensity, unleashed this sonic beast upon the world in their iconic "White Album."

The Surrealists were yet to come, their canvases bleeding with dreams. But long before, Henri Rousseau, alone in his studio, was crafting his own. Not just on canvas, but in the marrow of his bones. The Dream, 1910. A woman, eyes wide, bathed in the light of some strange, inner world.  And Rousseau himself, trapped in the labyrinth of his own striving. 

Recognition. Acceptance. The whisper of praise from those who knew the language of paint. A hunger gnawed at him, a yearning to be seen. But the world of art, cold and unforgiving, demanded conformity. To sculpt his dreams into the mold of expectation, or to stand apart, a lone figure in a howling wilderness? 

This was the battle raging within him, a battle painted across the years. 

Rousseau, born in the small town of Laval, was no child of privilege. His father, a tinsmith, his world a hard-scrabble existence.  No lessons in the academies, no gilded whispers of patronage. He toiled as a toll collector, a gabelou, his days measured out in the rhythm of passing carts and coins. Then, a cruel blow: the deaths of his wife and eight children, leaving only a daughter, Julia, to bind him to the world. He sought solace in paint, a language he learned by heart, a refuge from the ache in his soul.

He wasn't like the others, the artists who romanticized the peasant, the simple folk. He was one of them, his dreams as rooted in the soil as the wheat fields that stretched beyond his window. He knew the hunger, the yearning for something more than the daily grind. 

And so, he painted.

But the world of art, a jungle of talent and ambition, offered little comfort. Matisse rose, a comet streaking across the sky, while Rousseau remained in the shadows. He longed to be seen, to be welcomed into the fold, to be more than just a douanier with a brush.

"Matisse feared the trite," wrote Jan Gordon, "while Rousseau desired the conventional, the accepted," a desperate yearning to be deemed worthy.

The men of thought, they've pondered it long. This thing, this kinship between the right and the beautiful. Between truth and the eye's delight. Keats, he knew it, said it plain. "Beauty is truth, truth beauty—" That's all you know on this earth, and all you need to know.

We learn, we're taught. Facts and figures, how to live in this world. But ethics, aesthetics, these things they seep into you. Not through lessons, but through the marrow. Like a wind that blows through the trees, shaping them, whispering secrets.  

We study art, we dissect it. We weigh morality, try to pin it down. But it's a slippery thing. Like smoke, it eludes our grasp. We talk of foreground, of shadow and light, of context. Yet these words, they fall short.  There's something else, something that lingers. A ghost in the machine, as it were.

A favorite book, a piece of music that stirs the soul. We struggle to explain it. "There's just something about it," we say. And it's true. There's a something that transcends the words, the brushstrokes, the notes. A hollowness, an ache, a longing.

It's the same with morals. We can lay out the rules, the dos and don'ts. But the heart, the soul, it knows a different kind of truth. A truth that can't be contained, can't be explained.

Literature, now that's a thing apart. It's the closest we come to touching this other world.  McKean, he understood it. "Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there."

Morality and art, they're two sides of the same coin. They speak to us on a level deeper than words. They touch the soul, the very core of who we are.

The Germany of now, a fist clenched in the world's hand. A nation forged in the shadow of the Alps, a chill wind blowing from München to the salt spray of Kiel. The same blood runs through Köln's veins on the Rhine, through the heart of the land, to Dresden, a city cradled by the Elbe. It's a tapestry woven from disparate threads, a culture spun from the whispers of tribes long gone.

Germania. The name itself a ghost, a whisper echoing through the ages. Scholars, they scratch and claw at its meaning, but the truth lies buried deep. Tacitus, he claimed it belonged to the Tungrians, a people who crossed the Rhine, their swords singing a song of war against the Gauls. (Tacitus, 98.) Caesar, that butcher of men, he first used the word "Germanus," a label to distinguish the conquered Gauls from those who held fast to their land. Taken from the Gauls themselves, a word meant to mark the difference, the line between victors and the vanquished. Some say it came from the Gaulish tongue, a word for neighbor, a word turned weapon. Caesar, in his own blood-soaked chronicle, writes of them: "Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles." (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others whisper of the spear, the "ger," a weapon wielded in the heart of battle. Or perhaps from the Old Irish word, "garim," meaning "to shout," a testament to their fierce voices that echoed across the plains. (Names of Germany)

Tacitus, his pen a scalpel dissecting history, wrote in his "De Origine et situ Germanorum," a testament to the origins of these people. "I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal," he wrote, "and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98)

Rome, a colossus, looked upon Germania with a cold curiosity. They sought its riches, its furs, its amber. They sent their legions, their swords tasting the blood of the Germanic tribes, but Rome, in the end, turned its gaze elsewhere. The tribes, they lived on the edges, trading their wares, their skills, their blood in the ranks of the Roman legions. (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The pit yawned open below. I looked in.  Mind a blank slate, the picture etched itself there.  No emotion, no judgment. Just the cold, clear gaze of a thing seeing.  Thoughts, wisps of smoke, rose and vanished in the stillness.  The world flowed through me, a river of light and shadow. No thoughts of my own, just the current.

Once, an artist I knew, his eyes like chips of flint, told me of a book, *The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain*.  He said it taught you to see. To see the way a pencil moved, the way the world itself was made of lines.  He said to frame your vision, box it in, until all that was left was the essence. A bowl of fruit, not a kitchen, not a life.  Just the bowl.

The bowl before me now. I could not frame it.  It choked me, suffocated me.  Picasso with his blues, Monet with his greens, the Italians with their riot of colors.  This was my palette, the brown of the earth, the brown of decay.  Work in Brown, I thought.

My fingers brushed the cold porcelain. Muscles tensed, then slacked.  The will to shape, to mold, to create.  The water, a mirror of the sky, calm and deep.  A flake, a whisper, a moment of detachment.  Muscles tightened, a struggle, a spasm.  The handle slammed down.  Nothing.  A stubborn knot, a lump of defiance.

Mop in hand, tie a noose around my throat, I stared.  A message, scrawled in brown ink.  More flushes, more silence.  Then, the paper.  A slow, deliberate movement, wrapping, concealing.  Like a grave digger, preparing the earth.  My hand plunged in, a mother gathering her child.

The young ones are dying behind the wheel.  A confluence of things, a tangle of roots, brings them to this reckoning. The Institutes, they say, the brain ain't fully formed yet.  Not ready for the reckoning of the road. And inexperience, that's the heart of it.  A raw nerve that bleeds out in fatal crashes, in vehicles rolled like dying beasts, in reckless speed and the edge of the asphalt.

They're worse, these young ones, with their kind amongst them.  A fact known to any man with a lick of sense.  The Center in California, they studied it, the age of the passenger and the accidents they brought.  A grim dance.

States, they try.  Provisional licenses, they call 'em.  Hours limited, friends kept at bay.  But these are just bandages on a gunshot wound.  The truth is, they ain't ready.  Not by the numbers. Not by the cold, hard facts.  Doctor Zuckerman, he says it plain.  Eighteen, too young.  The young ones, they crave the rush, the thrill of the edge.  It's in their blood.  Delay the wheel, he says, let the hunger fade.

We keep handing out licenses, though.  And the dead pile up.  More soon, when the boomers' children come of age. Millions of them, hungry for the road.  A reckoning waits.

The law, it ain't hard to write.  Schools, they can teach, but no hands on the wheel 'til eighteen.  A permit, maybe, and hours behind the wheel with a guide.  Six hours, fifty hours, the numbers are already there.  Across the states, a uniform law, a national shield.

Not a new idea, no.  But maybe, just maybe, it's time we made it real.

The Library of Congress, a monument to the dead past, housed a collection of Edison's early films. I set out to watch them all, fifteen or so, from the waning years of the century to the dawning of the new. Trick films, they were called, illusions conjured by the cut and splice of celluloid. My study leaned toward the poetics of these tricks, the common thread that wove them together, and the few that dared to break free, to stray from the path.  

Mostly, these early films were bound to the stage, confined within a frame as rigid as a proscenium. The camera, a silent observer, never moved. It held its ground, a drone in the eye, capturing the world in long shots, medium shots, never a close-up. The one-shot rule held true, each idea, each flicker, captured in a single, unbroken take.

The set, the stage, it was always there, a constricting presence. Figures moved side to side, like marionettes on strings, never approaching or receding, never truly leaving the frame.  Look at "Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel," a phantom from 1900. The actors, shadows in the gloom, step in from the right, vanish into the darkness, but the camera, unblinking, holds its gaze.

The proscenium, a cage, dictated the form. The audience, like spectators in a darkened theater, saw the whole world at once, framed by the edges of the stage.  The actors, tethered to the middle ground, never breached the boundaries. Close-up, intimacy, a foreign concept.

Each film, a single idea, a single shot, told in a minute or less.  A glimpse, a trick, a vanishing act, a story whispered and gone. But be wary, for the illusion is a lie. What appears as a single shot may be many, stitched together, a tapestry woven from fragments. Look closer at "The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots," a relic from 1895.  The severed head, a phantom flicker, a trick of the light, a joining of disparate moments.

John Taylor of Caroline. A man of the soil. A farmer. And though the fields were his calling, the soil itself spoke to him of freedom, of self-reliance. A man made by the land, he saw the government then as a reflection of that land, and in his mind, the land was best left untamed, fiercely independent. He spoke of republics, of rights, of a Constitution meant to be a fence, not a cage. He believed in the nature of man, the darkness and the light, and that a government too strong would only fan those flames. He saw the dangers of a hungry power, a government swollen by ambition, and he saw the virtue in the simple life, the life of the farmer, the life lived close to the earth. The Declaration, he said, was the real testament, a whisper of sovereignty from the heart of the nation. A nation of states, not a single, monolithic whole. He wanted the government small, its reach limited, its touch light, lest it smother the very thing it sought to protect.

The chart, Figure Seventeen, tells a story. A stark drop in commuter logs the third month in. A discouragement, to be sure. Why this fall? Winter's bite had settled on the New England bones. Fewer souls walking or pedaling to class. December, the semester's end, a flurry of grades and deadlines. The log, a forgotten thing in the clamor. Then the holidays, that long shadow swallowing the campus, students and faculty dispersed. January, a slow awakening, classes stirring. Still, February, the logs remained scant. 

Perhaps the initial spark, that first burst of interest, had faded. A natural thing, maybe. So they built a Carpool Challenge Week, a firestorm in March, to reignite the flame. It worked, the logs climbed again. But the challenge remained: to hold the light against the winter of disengagement, against the cycles of school and season.

Another challenge: the allure of the car, an ingrained hunger for freedom, for the open road. A cultural beast. To lure them away, you need bait. They offered trinkets, gift cards to coffee shops and bookstores, even massages. But what of bigger prizes? A bicycle, a sleek hybrid, a silent electric dream? Perhaps that would have kept the logs full, year-round. The prizes remained the same, a meager offering against the siren song of the engine. 

What if the prizes, like the winter sky, grew brighter? Imagine, a promise whispered in December: a bicycle, a reward for the journey ahead. Then in January, bolder still: a hybrid, a whisper of the future. Maybe then, the logs would have sung a different song.

The ticker, they call it ETF, for Exchange Traded Fund. A cage, you might say, holding a collection of stocks, commodities, or even a phantom index. Like a stock, it moves on the boards, bought and sold in a flash.  But within that cage, a whole world. Diversification, they promise, spread thin against risk. Yet, a closer look reveals a price to pay. A commission for each trade, a toll to cross the threshold.

There are whispers, too, of expense ratios, lower than the old mutual funds, but still a weight on the scales. And the question lingers: does this cage truly offer the spread promised? Does owning a single ETF truly mirror the spread of a hand-picked portfolio?

We'll take IHF, a cage of its own, and examine its contents. The ten strongest holdings, they say, make up  more'n sixty percent of the cage's worth.  We'll compare these ten, these individual souls, to the cage itself. Will they sing the same song? Will their returns match the cage's, or will they offer a different tune altogether?  

We'll speak in numbers, in terms of Beta and Return, the metrics of the trade. But remember, numbers can lie. They can paint a picture, but the truth often hides in the shadows. We'll need to dig deeper, to look beyond the surface, to see if the cage's promise holds true.

Dream-land. One of Poe's own words, he called it a better poem. In it, he speaks of Thulé, a word echoed twice, like a ghost, in lines six and fifty-six. Mabbott traces it back to Virgil, the old man who wrote of an island north of Britain, a place the Greeks reckoned the world's edge. Virgil, he used it, that's for sure. But there's a newer whisper, a breath from across the sea, a German wind. Poe, he had eyes for those writers, spoke their tongue in his own way.

Karl J. Arndt, in his book, he lays it out plain: Poe's Politian and Goethe's Mignon. The echo there, Arndt says, is more than a passing fancy. Poe, he was mimicking the master.

Oxford, they speak of Goethe, a writer celebrated for his Faust, a play in two parts, the first born in eighteen-oh-eight, the second in the year of his dying, eighteen-thirty-two. And within that second part, a poem sings, "The King of Thulé." A king, his queen gone, the gift of a goblet, now a tomb in his hand. He drinks, he weeps, remembers. Then, a hollow echo in his heart, he knows his time is come. He gives his all to his children, keeps the goblet, a cold comfort. To the cliff he walks, throws the goblet into the sea, closes his eyes, and follows it down, down, down.

The King of Thulé, Poe's dreamer, a shadow, maybe, of loss, of a bottle's hollow embrace. Faust, it was made into a play, a drama of shadows by H.P. Grattan in eighteen-forty-two, a year before Poe's own dark use of the word "Thulé" in "The Pit and the Pendulum."

Twice in his own words, Poe speaks of Thulé. "Ulma Thule" in the Pendulum, a whisper. But in "Dream-land," it hangs, a bookend, twice repeated. "The King of Thulé," "Dream-land," they stand together, companions in the dark. In "Dream-land," the speaker walks the landscape of Thulé, a place of shadows, of loneliness, ghosts whispering at his heel, a world drained of color.  Goethe's poem, the king's grief, his emptiness, his world turned to ash, it's all there, mirrored in Poe's words.

Goethe, he was a giant, a writer Poe couldn't help but know, even if only for the sake of Tennyson.  "I admire Tennyson," Poe said, and behind that, a world of echoes, of shared words and borrowed dreams.

The law in this godforsaken state holds that a man who slips on a spilled jar of applesauce, his bones brittle and his life laid out like a map of misery, might find some measure of justice in the coin of punitive damages. The question hangs heavy: can a man claim such recompense when the manager, a man named Martin, turned a blind eye to the slick trail of fruit, twice warned of its treachery?

The judge, a hardened soul forged in the fires of a thousand petty disputes, ain't likely to toss this claim out with the morning's trash. To win such damages, the plaintiff, a woman named Palmer, must show that Martin's actions weren't just negligent, but steeped in a willful disregard for the fate of his customers.  She'll argue that Martin knew, or should have known, the danger. The years before were stained with the blood of other spills, other broken bodies. He'd heard the cries, seen the fallen, yet still he chose the comfort of his supper over the safety of his store. Whether his actions are truly "despicable," a word that tastes like ash on the tongue, is a matter for the jury to decide.

The facts are cold and stark. On a day in October, a man named Wayne, a servant in Martin's domain, brought word of the spilled applesauce. Martin, his belly full of the bounty of the earth, offered only a dismissive shrug. Another servant, Haddigan, came bearing the same news, but Martin's ears were deaf to her pleas.  And then came Palmer, her life shattered on the slick floor, her back a twisted monument to Martin's indifference.

The law, a labyrinth of words and precedents, offers a sliver of hope for the injured. It speaks of malice, of a disregard for human life that borders on cruelty. It whispers of punishment, of a reckoning for the man who turns a blind eye to the suffering of others.

Four years gone now since I sat in that classroom at CBC, the air thick with the dust of scripture and the friction of belief. We wrestled with the question then, a question that hangs heavier still in this time: was Islam a hostile faith? The world, spit from the fire of 9/11, had watched the media shift its gaze, from the scorn of suspicion to a blanket of uneasy acceptance. A name like Barack Obama, a name that echoed with the murmur of a distant faith, could scarcely have been uttered in the year 2001.

The Prophet’s story, it drew me in, not for its glory, but for the dissonance it held. I’d been taught of conquest, of tribes forced under the yoke of Islam, their voices stifled by the sword. Yet the biography painted a different picture, a man humbled, misunderstood, a martyr even. People drawn to him, not by force, but by a conviction that bloomed slowly, like a flower in the desert.

There are echoes in the stories, whispers of the miracles wrought by Jesus. The multiplying mutton and milk, a feast made from nothing. A narrative spun to paint Muhammad as a man of unwavering faith, untouched by the need for worldly validation. A shadow falls across this, a suspicion that the sun of Christ’s divinity is being eclipsed by a borrowed light.

And the witnesses, their voices echoing through generations, filtered through the haze of hearsay. A chain of whispers, each link growing flimsier, the truth obscured.

Perhaps the most unsettling aspect is the attempt to elevate Muhammad, to cast him as a godlike figure, gentle, wise, compassionate. History, however, tells a different tale, a tale of a man forged in the fires of ambition. I wonder, do those who follow him today know the truth, the weight of the past?

The words the man called Jesus spoke, the truths he held dear, were cast aside like chaff on the wind the moment he was gone.  The cloth of Christian thought, once woven with his threads, took on a life of its own, twisting and turning, straying further from its source with every passing generation. The world, it seems, marches ever onward, a procession of progress, a relentless tide of change. The old ways cling, sure, like barnacles to a hull, but they are few and brittle. They cannot hold back the rising tide. There will come a time, a reckoning, when the dust settles and the true heart of the matter is revealed. A yearning will rise, a hunger to strip away the layers of dogma, to see the man behind the myth, the words behind the pronouncements. It will be a long road, paved with centuries perhaps, but the path is set. The clock will turn backward, unwinding the centuries of accretion, until only the bare bones of Jesus' message remain. And when this tide washes over the land, drowning the false idols in its wake, the church itself, that ancient edifice, will stand strong, a beacon in the returning darkness. But the faith it guards will be transformed. The vast, splintered multitude of Christendom will coalesce, drawn together by a single, unwavering faith. The differences that have plagued them for centuries will fade, swallowed by the rising tide. This is the way of things, the way of history. It is the cycle of empires, the pendulum swing. From persecution to power, from darkness to light, from slavery to freedom. And now, it will turn once more, on the altar of faith. The great reversion is coming, a return to the source, a stripping bare of the soul. And to make this possible, the words of Jesus will be read anew, not as pronouncements from on high, but as whispers from the heart, metaphors for a deeper truth.

So tell me, what has transpired since the day he walked this earth? What has been added, what has been lost? 

Look back through the mists of time, and you will find only Judaism, the seed from which Christianity sprouted.  The belief in a single God, the authority of the scriptures, the revelation of a divine will. These were the pillars upon which the faith stood when the Romans set their foot on Jerusalem in the year of our Lord 63 BC. But even then, the children of Israel were not one. They were divided, fractured into sects - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots - and the common folk who straddled the line between.

The belly of the beast. That's what Sinclair called it. The Jungle. And inside, men were no different than the animals they slaughtered. Greed. That was the root. It choked the air, thickened the blood, turned men's hearts to rust. The factory owners, men with eyes like cold steel, they saw only the bottom line. The smoke that poured from their chimneys, black as a sinner's soul, it was the breath of their hunger. They cared nothing for the men they chewed up and spit out, the women and children too frail to stand against the machine.  

Sinclair paints a picture, stark and unforgiving. Buildings like tombstones against the sky. Rivers of smoke, a shroud over the land.  The stench of death, of blood and offal, clung to everything. The men, their faces etched with grime and despair, they were shadows in the machine, cogs in a wheel grinding them down.

"From top to bottom," Sinclair wrote, "a seething cauldron." No loyalty, no decency. Just the cold, hard currency of dollars. They stole their lives. Their sweat, their blood, their very breath. And when they were spent, discarded, they were left to rot in the muck of Packingtown.

Even the unions, those supposed bastions of hope, they were but another hand reaching into the till.  Only the masters profited, the wolves in fine suits. The workers, they were trapped, slaves to a system that devoured them whole. Their cries, lost in the roar of the machines, echoed the emptiness of their souls.

The telling of a story, it ain't just words on a page. It's the feel you leave the reader with, the taste in their mouth. Some writers, they know this. Fitzgerald, he knew it good. He built worlds with words, not just told them. He'd take a word, an image, and twist it, make it mean more than it did on the surface.

Colors, he used them like that. Gold, green, white, gray, red, pink. Each one a whisper, a hint. He built meaning into them, slow and sure, like a house being brick by brick. White, he used for the pretty kind of things, the high class, the kind that fades with time. Gray, it was the opposite. Older, tired, worn down.

He'd sprinkle them through the story, white chins and gray faces, white roads and gray skies. Even the names of folks at Gatsby's parties, they were just gray smudges on a list. He'd paint with these colors, making the reader see the world through his eyes, feel the dust of the valley, the chill of the gray houses.

And then, when you least expect it, he'd use those colors to tell you something. Like Daisy, she was a white blur, a ghost in a white dress. A beautiful thing, maybe, but empty.  A white void, something Gatsby chased after but couldn't reach.

Fitzgerald, he knew how to use words. He knew how to make you feel.

The sun baked San Diego County, coaxing life from the soil. Tomatoes plumped, citrus hung heavy, a sea of green from leafy greens and squash stretching as far as the eye could see. Broccoli, herbs, peaches, lemons, berries, honey, peppers—all grew fat and sweet under the endless sky. A hunger for the clean, the natural, pulsed through the region. Organic food, a bounty from the earth untainted, was in demand. Community Supported Agriculture, letters carried on the wind from farm to table, had waiting lists stretching long as the desert shadows. Eggs and milk, organic and fresh, were sought after treasures. Farms, some open to the public, beckoned with tours, paths winding through the rows, birdsong a constant symphony. This was the kind of farm the land could bear, a place to honor the soil, to draw profit from the earth's bounty while keeping the wild things safe. A place where the government's hand could lend aid, not to stifle, but to nurture, where education and recreation could bloom alongside the crops.

But the path of the organic farmer is not paved with gold. It demands a different kind of toil, a constant vigilance. Weeds and pests, they come like shadows, and the chemicals that banish them are not options here. The soil must be coaxed, nurtured, and the yield, it is often smaller. The small farm, it lacks the scale, the economy of the giants, but in its heart beats the rhythm of a different kind of wealth.

Biodiversity, a tapestry of life, thrives where chemicals are banished. The earth breathes easier, the creatures find solace. But the cost, it is borne by the hands that labor, the sweat that stains the brow. Cover crops, grazing managed with care, the fight against invasive species—all these things demand time, attention, and a labor of love.

And so, the landowner in this story, he stands at a crossroads. He sees the potential, the promise of a land that yields both profit and life. But the path is not easy. He needs help, guidance, a hand to steady his steps.

The land itself, a tapestry woven from chaparral, the whispers of Mediterranean grasses, and the stoic presence of oak woodlands, lies just beyond the town of Potrero. It is a piece of the East County Southern Foothills, a realm where the Cleveland National Forest stretches out like a green embrace.  This land, it is part of a larger story, a conservation plan that seeks to protect the dwindling creatures, the kangaroo rat, the yellow-legged frog, the butterflies with wings of stained glass, the gnatcatcher, a songbird with a fragile voice.   

This land has known many lives. The ancient ones, the whispers of Native Americans, long before the trail of the cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers carved its way into the landscape.  Homestead claims, grants from a past long gone, a legacy of grazing, of wood, a whisper of what was and what could be again.  

A piece of property, found on a screen, a map of possibilities. Research, a search for the tools, the programs, the hands that could help shape this land into a haven. An example, a model of what could be, a farm in the same region, already living the dream.

Culture. A shadowed thing. As much what it ain't as what it is. Not some uniform cloth stitched tight. Not a single thread. To say all Russians are stubborn, all Japanese accommodating, that's a fool's cartography.  A map drawn with broad strokes, ignorance bleeding into the lines.  Understand the weight of a culture, sure, how it sits like a stone in the belly of a man. How it shapes the talk at the table. 

When you walk into a strange land, you see it through the lens of your own. Comparisons rise, like smoke from a fire. To know a foreign mind, you gotta dig deep. Into history, into the dark corners of its prejudices.  Don't judge. Don't try to change it. Accept it, the good and the bad. Work within its bones. Especially when you're at the table with a weaker hand. 

Culture ain't just bound by nations. It whispers in the halls of corporations too. Some places, the hours stretch long, the hours bleed into the night. Others, they move at a gentler pace. You see it in the way they dress, the words they choose, who they give power to. Some places, charity is a prayer whispered in the heart. Others, it's a ledger book, entries marked with the company's approval. Even in America, the heart of a company can beat different rhythms,  from city to town, from corner office to factory floor. 

Values. That's the heart of it.  The why. If saving face is sacred, a man won't break his own to win a deal. If hard bargaining is the creed, he won't back down easy. 

Know these things before you sit down at the table. But more than that, know the man across from you.  Look into his eyes.  That's where the real deal is made.

The fool, he’d said it in his heart. "There is no God." A line from the Psalms, they say, the book of psalms. A starting point for Anselm, that man, in his talk of a God. And Aquinas, he too held fast to this belief. Both men, wrestling with the same notion, the same God, the God of the Book. To compare them, we must first presume their ground is true, that God is, that he is the God they speak of. 

But what is this God? And does he need proving?

Anselm, he looked inward. Found God in the mind. Said that to conceive of his nonexistence was impossible. A tangled web, his words, but the thread was clear: the proof of God lies within. No need to seek him in the world, he said, only look to what the mind already knows. A kind of faith, this, a leap into the dark.

Aquinas, he went a different way. He sought proof in the world, in the things that could be seen and touched. Five arguments he laid out, like stones on a path: change, cause and effect, the fact that things are not eternal, the gradation of goodness, and the harmony of the universe. He said that logic itself pointed to God, that the existence of the world demanded a maker.

Both men, seeking the same truth, but by different roads. But do they truly reach it? Or is it just a shadow, a reflection in the mind?

The prince, he'd be known as Buddha some day. Born in the dusk of the fifth or sixth century before the reckoning. He cast off the world, found the light, and his words took root, blooming into Buddhism. The Theravada strain, the oldest branch, still clings to the roots. Yet it's a different world now, two and a half thousand years on. Look to Sri Lanka, a land of Theravada, where they cut the water each year in a ceremony. Monks and men, shoulder to shoulder. A ritual, no doubt, but one Buddha never spoke of.  The changes seep in, from the skin of the tradition to its bone. The Theravada people, both the robed and the lay, have had to bend and shift, their doctrines like driftwood in a tide.

There are forces at play, shaping the current. Inside forces, from those who walk the Buddhasasana path, whether cloaked or free. Outside forces, those from beyond the fold. Hostile forces, aiming to wound or break the community, born of spite or misunderstanding. And benign forces, indifferent to the river's flow, though they may leave a ripple in their wake. These forces, they'll echo through this telling.

First, the heart of the matter: the doctrines that hold Theravada firm.  Refuge is sought in the triple gem: Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha. The Dhamma, the teachings, are gathered in the Tripitaka, three baskets of wisdom. The Sutta Pitaka, the words of Buddha himself. The Vinaya Pitaka, the rules for living, the way of the monk and the lay. And lastly, the Abhidhamma Pitaka, the depths of being, where truths like Anatta—no soul—and Dukkha—the sting of life—and Anicca—the ever-changing world—are held. Only by knowing these can one escape Sansara, the endless wheel of birth and death. And with it, lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion—will fade, leaving only enlightenment.

The Vinaya Pitaka lays out the path for all. Five precepts for the lay: no killing, no lying, no stealing, no lust, no intoxicants. For the monks, a more intricate web of rules, a tighter leash.  But at the core, the Four Noble Truths. Life is Dukkha, that's the first. Attachment fuels the fire of suffering, the second. But there's a way out, the third. And the fourth: the path to freedom lies in the Eightfold Path.

The land of the Egyesült Államok and Mexico, two nations bound by a shared border, were once locked in a long-held feud. A feud that stretched like a serpent's shadow, from 1836 to the year 1893, a span of fifty-seven years. (Diehl and Goerts, 2000, p. 145).  The high tide of this conflict crested with the Mexican-American War, a storm of steel and fire from 1846 to 1848. The north, the Egyesült Államok, struck, and Mexico fell. Texas and the Southwest, lands rich with promise, were claimed for the victor. But skirmishes, smaller fires in the long night, continued to flicker between the two nations, fading finally on the eve of the Great War. 

The roots of this bitterness ran deep, tangled in the soil of differing faiths, customs, and ways of life.  Material interests, too, clashed, a grinding friction that set the two nations at odds. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 30-31). This dance of rivalry is not unique. Nations sharing a boundary, their fates intertwined, often find themselves locked in a struggle for dominance. Like echoes in the canyons, the United States and Mexico mirrored the jealousies and ambitions of nations wedged together by geography.  As Pletcher (1977) observed, "Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems" (p. 41). These nations, close in proximity, stood as rivals, while others in the south basked in a more amicable sun.

Religion, a potent force, cast a shadow over the relationship.  Frahm (2001) reminds us, "If in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy" (p. 86).  Like the Cold War, a clash of ideologies, the tensions between the United States and Mexico were woven from both belief and self-interest. Yet, the battleground was not political, but spiritual, a struggle over the soul of nations. This suspicion, born of the old world, lingered.  The English and Spanish, their shadows stretching back centuries, had sown the seeds of distrust, a legacy that poisoned the well of diplomacy.

Diehl and Goerts (2000) catalogued seventeen disputes between the two nations,  a litany of grievances stretching over fifty-seven years. Most were territorial skirmishes, echoes of the border wars: raids from one side into the other, outlaws seeking refuge in the lawless spaces between.  Bandits and lawbreakers, their motives as tangled as the barbed wire fences, fueled the flames of conflict.  It wasn't until both nations, weary of the endless struggle, committed their armies to the border that the violence finally receded. (Schmitt, 1974, p. 97).

Schmitt (1974) argues that the rivalry waned as Mexico, like a supplicant, found itself increasingly reliant on the north.  By the late nineteenth century, the Egyesült Államok’s ambitions shifted from conquest to economic control, their sights fixed on the riches of Mexico. And so, the long-held feud, like a dying ember, finally flickered out. (p. 109, p. 110).

Fifteen years gone now. A sickness came on sudden, unexpected. A thing I'd never known. I was a nurse then.  A trade chosen out of a need for the kind of security I'd lacked as a boy.  "You'll always be needed," they'd said. "Folks always get sick." A mantra hammered home from adolescence on. So I took to the wards, even though the dream had been a different kind.  Science, maybe.  Journalism.  A little of both, if you please. But the dream, well, it faded.

Then came the fall. Forty-six years on this earth, single, no savings to speak of, and the work, it left me. Still does. Fifteen years of living on what the government allows, and I'm left with nothing.  Nothing that's truly mine. I make do, but each day is a fight, a gnawing at the edges of my security, my safety, my pride.  Nothing certain anymore except this: I wouldn't have made it without the hand of my family, a few good souls.  And let me tell you, when the real disaster strikes,  strength ain't much more than a whisper.

Life throws you curves, big and small.  No guarantees. No matter how you plan, there are things too vast to face alone. 

They talk about small government, the "rugged individualism" that built this land.  But truth is, what got our forefathers through wasn't grit, it was the helping hand, the shared load, the kindness between men.  Those pioneers who crossed the Rockies, they didn't do it alone. They relied on each other.

So yes, be prepared.  I am.  Got my kit: flashlight, batteries, candles, matches, canned goods.  Water tablets, plastic sheeting for the windows, just in case.  If you've got the land, the means, a small farm, can your own food.  A wood stove, if you're lucky enough to have a place for it.

But while you're at it, get to know your neighbors. That's the real strength.

The why of things. The turning of the forms. Why do they take the shape they do?  Are there unseen hands guiding them, constraints upon their becoming?  D’Arcy Thompson spoke of it long ago, a truth still felt in the marrow: "Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms."  True enough then, and true now.  

But the tools have sharpened.  Mathematical models, they've been applied to the making of the shells, the skeletogenesis of the mollusks, through the crawling of time, the ontogeny, and the branching of lineage, the phylogeny.  Raup and Stanley, they laid it out back in '81.  

Our work, it probes this further.  Using the Prunum, a spiral of the sea, we seek to understand what forces shape its form, the direction and measure of its change.  We took X-rays, peering into the bones, drawing lines of measurement, feeding them into the belly of the machine, CerioShell, a program spun from code. We spun models, hypothetical forms, ghosts of shells yet to be, to see the edges of what is possible.  These we marry with the flesh and blood, the living study, to pierce the veil of time, to see the grand sweep of change in this lineage.

A shell, it's a tube, a journey through three hundred and sixty degrees of space, a spiral unwinding. Each turn, a whorl, spiraling around a central axis, the columella.  The speed of this unwinding, it varies. A suture, a scar, marks the path between whorls.  The last whorl, the body whorl, it's the grandest, the final flourish. The rest, the spire, a silent symphony of turns. The apex, the tip, points skyward.  The base, the opposite end, rests upon the earth.  And through an aperture, a mouth, the creature emerges.

We look at the shell from above, from below, from the front, from the back.  The aperture, it's the face, the window to the world.  We count the whorls, tracing the line of the suture, dividing the shell, measuring the journey.

A shell, it's a story told in space and time. Each whorl, a chapter, a moment captured.  We can chart its path, the center of each aperture, the radius of its span, and write its story in the language of numbers.

And with this language, we can twist the threads, change the parameters, and see how the form might shift, how evolution dances its intricate dance.

The death rattle of babes and babes yet unsprung had held a stubborn stillness in Indonesia these last ten years. The nation moved, it seemed, on a path toward the ghosts of promised goals: water and sanitation targets met, perhaps. But the health of mothers and children, that was a different song altogether. A song of want and hunger, sung in the language of numbers far too high, far too woeful. The reasons for this, they lie buried in the heart of the matter, in the bones of the country's own making. To mend this, a stronger spine is needed, not more patchwork remedies.

72% of births now saw the face of a skilled hand, they say. But skilled is a word that holds many shades. Midwives, wise women of tradition, could not mend a womb torn asunder. Hemorrhage, the crimson flood, claimed its victims still. Progress, then, a thin veneer, a brittle shell. And the children, those small souls under five, their battles with the gut-wrenching grip of diarrhea, they fought alone more often than not. Data on the care given after birth, a shadow story, but even in its darkness, the lack of care, the absence of touch, it whispers a chilling truth.

The knife's cold kiss, the cesarean, it was rare. 4% of births bore this mark. But in the city, it danced at 7%, while in the villages, it lingered at a paltry 2%. A chasm, a gulf, between the haves and the have-nots, exposed. The lifeblood of health, it flowed in the veins of the city, leaving the countryside parched. And the poor, they were choked by the weight of coins, their pockets empty, their access to care a distant dream. A 27% gap, a canyon bridged by nothing but despair.

What then, is the path forward? To build new programs, like towers of hope, or to strengthen the very foundations of the system itself? The siren song of quick fixes, of targeted programs, it calls. Easier to manage, to measure, to claim victory. But a house built on shifting sand, it crumbles in the wind. Resources drain, poured into one well, leaving others to wither. And the machinery of bureaucracy, it grows fat on paperwork, on forms, on an endless cycle of waste.

The Victorians, they wrote of detail, of the gilded cages of their age. But two tales, they stray from the thread. *Oliver Twist* and *Wuthering Heights*, they whisper of shadows and strangeness. A darkness that lingers in the corners of the soul. These tales weave a mystery, a kind of fevered dream that clings to the characters, seeping into their bones. It's in the whispers of their fears, in the way their eyes betray what their words cannot. 

Consider this: A boy, lost in a labyrinth of his own making. *“And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, … he found that he was talking to them…. Suddenly he started back at the report of fire arms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which weared and tormented him incessantly.”* (Dickens, 220) 

The boy, Oliver, adrift in a sea of pain and confusion. He is haunted by the echoes of violence, his mind a battlefield of conflicting images. He is a puppet dancing on the strings of fate, unable to control the darkness that closes in around him.

The mystery, it seeps into the dreams, into the waking hours. Like a slow poison, it unravels the fabric of reality. In *Oliver Twist*, these dreams are a glimpse into the boy's soul, a window into the horrors he has witnessed and the pain he carries within.

The shooting, it hangs over him like a shroud. A relived agony, a constant reminder of his vulnerability. He is consumed by the pain, his senses numbed to the world around him. He is a hollow shell, a ghost in his own life.

The question lingers: who is to blame? Is it the cruelty of the world, or the weakness of his own spirit? The novel leaves the answer unresolved, a haunting echo that lingers in the silence.

Two years gone. I was workin' in one of them after-school programs, mindin' kids, see. Elementary age. Tried to help 'em out with whatever ailed their learnin', but English, that was my trade. Readin', writin', that was where I shone. Got pulled aside by one of the teachers, a man named Ramirez, about a boy named Adrian. Third or fourth grade, somethin' like that. Adrian, he was havin' a right mess with the readin'.

At first, I couldn't make heads or tails of it. Letters, see, he'd nail some, spit 'em out clean. Others, he'd garble 'em somethin' fierce. Like he was speakin' a tongue I couldn't grasp. Knew he was Latino, that much was plain. But the boy, he spoke English like a native. Struggled on for a spell, we did. Till one day, Adrian's mama walked in. The rest of the kids were away on some field trip, leavin' me holdin' the fort with a bunch of rambunctious youngsters. Her, she didn't speak a lick of English. Just Spanish, plain and simple. Had a go at it, I did, with the little Spanish I'd picked up. Barely enough to get by. But then it hit me, like a blow to the gut: Adrian, he wasn't readin' wrong. He just didn't know the damn alphabet. Not the English one, that is.

Don't know if that revelation helped him much, but I hope he's doin' better now.

That story, I tell it to show the problem of language, the walls it builds in our schools. Especially here in California, where the tongues are many. It ain't always as clear-cut as we think. Even a boy who speaks English like a bird, readin' can be a mountain he can't climb.

We all know the problem's there. So what's the fix? For Adrian, it was simple enough: a little extra help with readin', learnin' the alphabet, how the sounds come out. But for the kids who barely speak English at all, well, that's a whole other beast. Ain't no one answer. Dual language, immersion, tutors, ESL classes, none of it alone will do the trick. It's a mix, a blendin' of all those things.

Dual language, that's a good start. Not just for kids whose first tongue is Spanish, but for all of 'em. Studies show, kids in these kinda programs, they do better. Some folks, they fear it, say it wastes time and money. That the majority of kids won't benefit. But that's a lie. If we made these programs the rule, not the exception, every child would come out ahead.

How do we do it? Do we make every teacher bilingual?  That's a tall order, ain't it? Unrealistic, maybe. But what if we had folks, aides, tutors, somethin' like that, who spoke both tongues? That'd be a start.

From the time the light first found its way into your eyes they told you there was something out there. Something vast. Something beyond the ken of man. Some were sent to the house of the Lord, others to the synagogue, others still to the silence within. Faith, a hand-me-down garment, often worn without question. But some, they tore the seams, the fabric unraveling, leaving them naked in a universe of their own making.  A universe where the only truth was the echo of their own beating heart.  And so they wandered.  Each a pilgrim searching for their own light in the dark.

“A cardinal,” he said, voice rasping like wind through dry leaves. His eyes, fixed on the rain drumming on the tin roof, saw something more than the water.  Something lost. Something remembered.  The porch, shrouded in a grey mist, whispered of the things that were and the things that would be.  He was thinner now, his clothes hanging loose on his frame, a sparrow in a cage too big for him.  His hair, sparse and wispy, like the smoke from his cigarette, drifting upwards into the storm clouds.  He didn't look at me.  I sat there, the silence a heavy shroud.  Words, useless, tangled in my throat.  I reached out, a hand over his shoulder, and drew him closer.  We watched the rain, two souls caught in the current of time.

He died in December, five days after I turned twenty-two.  The doctors, they said it was a mercy.  But mercy for whom?  He lingered, a ghost in a fading light, his suffering a silent plea.  I thought then, if there was a God, he had turned his back on us both.  I said no prayers.  There was no solace in the whispers of the dead, no comfort in the words of the living.

I couldn't watch him go.  Not like that.  I wanted to remember him as he was, not as he became.  I knew him better than anyone else.  He wouldn't have wanted me there.  So I stayed away.  Curled up in my bed, in the darkness, waiting for the news.  And the news never came.

The Gothic, Watt called it an oxymoron, "Old-New." A contradiction in terms.  Praised and damned. Shallow and profound.  A haunted mirror peering into the terrible sublime. Walpole, he built the first one, The Castle of Otranto.  Old playhouse ghosts and new world whispers, a novel born of two eras. He called it "A Gothic Story." 

The word itself, "Gothic." A whisper of the past, a stain of the old ways, a shadow of something grand and fallen. Archaic, they said. Unsophisticated.  But Walpole, he saw something else, something buried beneath the dust. He saw the drama, the spectacle, the lingering echo of a time when men were men and battles were fought with honor. He took that old world, that chivalric fire, and he poured it into the new form of the novel, where the reader walks beside the knight, feels the weight of his soul. 

And so the Gothic endures. The past, forever present.

Chivalry, that's the heart of it. The knight, the ideal. Brave, honorable, a shield against the darkness.  But the world, it had changed.  The old ways were fading. Walpole, he saw that. He saw the decay, the corruption. And in that decay, he saw a reflection of himself, a man caught in the storm, a witness to a world losing its way.

Frederic, his knight, his hero.  He carries the weight of the past, the burden of a fallen world.  A prince, a victim, a shadow of the knight he might have been.

That's the Gothic.  A haunted house. A broken hero. A world struggling to remember its own soul.

The flow of goods, a restless serpent from the point of order to the raw earth, through the forge of production, the arteries of supply, the weight of distribution, and finally to the waiting hands of the customer. The term, "supply chain management," a cold coinage minted in 1982 by a man named Keith Oliver, a consultant in the trade, speaks of planning, of execution, and of control, all aimed at satisfying the hunger of the customer with speed and a certain grim efficiency.  Six pillars hold this chain aloft: production, supply, the hoard of inventory, the placement of facilities, the ceaseless motion of transportation, and the pulse of information. These are the tools the managers wield, striving to offer comfort to the consuming world.

Production, the first beat of the heart, is the foundation. It lays bare the when, the why, the where, and the how of creation.  Managers must know the desires of the market, for the market is a mirror reflecting the wants of the many. The murmur of demand guides their hand, dictating what will be wrought and in what quantity. Once the vision is clear, the managers turn their attention to the forge, seeking the place where the goods will take shape, where volume and quality will coalesce.  The customer's need must always be the north star.  The rhythm of work, the care of the machinery, these are the next steps, each detail a thread in the tapestry of the process. A misstep, a flaw in the design, can unravel the whole, costing time and money like a leaking vessel.   I've seen this myself, working in the great stores, Wal-Mart and Target, where each task, from the uniform of the worker to the delivery of a truckload, is meticulously outlined.  Such order ensures the smooth flow of commerce, a symphony of motion without discord.

The second pillar is supply, the lifeblood coursing through the veins of the chain. It is the art of choosing, of selecting the core capabilities of a facility, of forging partnerships with those who can offer strength and speed.  A single product may be born in many workshops, each with its own tools, its own people, its own expertise. The manager must be a weaver, threading these threads together, aligning the right division with the right process. Sometimes, the wise manager chooses to relinquish control, to outsource the work to others, seeking velocity, that elusive quality of speed and flexibility, while keeping the cost low, a tightrope walk between efficiency and expense.

The sign sagged in her hand, the words a jagged script against the cardboard: Hitler is alive in Burma. Ellen Page, a face from some distant movie, stood alone on the cracked asphalt, her vigil a lonely island in the flow of indifferent traffic. Burma. Myanmar. A place where the sun beat down on a country ruled by shadows, a junta that had seized power in the dust of a coup, decades gone.
